events.originalText: President Martín Vizcarra dissolved the Congress of Peru, resulting in a constitutional crisis.
events.subtitle: Martín Vizcarra
events.headline: President Martín Vizcarra dissolves Congress of Peru, sparking constitutional crisis

events.originalText: A 7.6 MW earthquake struck off the southern coast of Sumatra, Indonesia, killing 1,115 and impacting an estimated 1.2 million people.
events.subtitle: Moment magnitude scale
events.headline: 7.6 MW earthquake in Sumatra, Indonesia kills 1,115 and affects 1.2 million

events.originalText: The Danish newspaper Jyllands-Posten published controversial editorial cartoons depicting Muhammad, sparking protests across the Muslim world by many who viewed them as Islamophobic and blasphemous.
events.subtitle: Jyllands-Posten
events.headline: Controversial Muhammad cartoons published by Danish newspaper, ignite global protests

events.originalText: Twelve-year-old Muhammad al-Durrah was shot dead in the Gaza Strip; the Israel Defense Forces initially accepted responsibility but retracted it five years later.
events.subtitle: Killing of Muhammad al-Durrah
events.headline: 12-year-old Muhammad al-Durrah shot dead in Gaza Strip, IDF initially claims responsibility

events.originalText: The Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers (ICANN), a nonprofit organization that manages the assignment of domain names and IP addresses in the Internet, was incorporated.
events.subtitle: ICANN
events.headline: ICANN incorporated to manage domain names and IP addresses on the Internet

events.originalText: Cheers, an American television sitcom, debuted with its pilot episode on NBC.
events.subtitle: Cheers
events.headline: Cheers sitcom debuts on NBC

events.originalText: The Boeing AH-64 Apache (example pictured), the primary attack helicopter for a number of countries, made its first flight.
events.subtitle: Boeing AH-64 Apache
events.headline: Boeing AH-64 Apache makes first flight as primary attack helicopter

events.originalText: Members of the 30 September Movement attempted a coup against the Indonesian government that was crushed by the military under Suharto, leading to a mass anti-communist purge with more than 500,000 people killed over the following months.
events.subtitle: 30 September Movement
events.headline: 30 September Movement coup attempt in Indonesia crushed, leading to mass anti-communist purge

events.originalText: American film actor James Dean suffered fatal injuries in a head-on car accident near Cholame, California.
events.subtitle: James Dean
events.headline: James Dean dies in car accident near Cholame, California

events.originalText: Second World War: General Władysław Sikorski (pictured) became the first prime minister of the Polish government-in-exile.
events.subtitle: World War II
events.headline: General Władysław Sikorski becomes first prime minister of Polish government-in-exile

events.originalText: NBC broadcast the first televised American football game, between the Fordham Rams and the Waynesburg Yellow Jackets.
events.subtitle: NBC
events.headline: First televised American football game broadcast by NBC

events.originalText: Adolf Hitler, Benito Mussolini, Neville Chamberlain, and Édouard Daladier signed the Munich Agreement, stipulating that Czechoslovakia must cede the Sudetenland to Germany.
events.subtitle: Adolf Hitler
events.headline: Hitler, Mussolini, Chamberlain, and Daladier sign Munich Agreement for Sudetenland

events.originalText: Times Square Theater (pictured) opened on Broadway with a production of The Mirage, a play written by its owner, Edgar Selwyn.
events.subtitle: Times Square Theater
events.headline: Times Square Theater opens on Broadway with production of The Mirage

events.originalText: Nestor Makhno and Fedir Shchus led insurgents to successfully ambush the Central Powers that occupied southern Ukraine during World War I.
events.subtitle: Nestor Makhno
events.headline: Insurgents led by Makhno and Shchus ambush Central Powers in southern Ukraine

events.originalText: The Vulcan Street Plant in Appleton, Wisconsin, the first hydroelectric central station to serve a system of private and commercial customers in North America, went online.
events.subtitle: Vulcan Street Plant
events.headline: Vulcan Street Plant in Appleton, Wisconsin goes online as first hydroelectric central station in North America

events.originalText: Georges Bizet's opera Les pêcheurs de perles premiered at the Théâtre Lyrique in Paris.
events.subtitle: Georges Bizet
events.headline: Bizet's opera Les pêcheurs de perles premieres in Paris

events.originalText: Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart's opera The Magic Flute, composed shortly before his death, premiered at Theater auf der Wieden in Vienna.
events.subtitle: Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart
events.headline: Mozart's opera The Magic Flute premieres in Vienna

events.originalText: Sue Takafusa, a retainer of the Ōuchi clan in western Japan, led a coup against the daimyō Ōuchi Yoshitaka, leading to the latter's forced suicide.
events.subtitle: Sue Harukata
events.headline: Ōuchi clan retainer leads coup against daimyō Ōuchi Yoshitaka in Japan

events.originalText: A violent earthquake struck the Caucasus near Ganja, killing up to an estimated 300,000 people.
events.subtitle: 1139 Ganja earthquake
events.headline: Violent earthquake in Caucasus near Ganja claims up to 300,000 lives

events.originalText: Muslim conquest of Transoxiana: Türgesh tribesmen attacked and captured the exposed baggage train of the Umayyad army, sent ahead of the main force.
events.subtitle: AD 737
events.headline: Türgesh tribesmen capture Umayyad army's baggage train in Muslim conquest of Transoxiana
